biography: Dr. Jane Doe is an Assistant Professor of Geology at Texas State University. Dr. Doe completed her PhD in Science at the University of Chicago in 2001. Prior to joining the Texas State faculty, she worked as a researcher in NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory at the California Institute of Technology. Dr. Doe is a member of the American Institute of Professional Geologists, the Association for Women Geoscientists, and the Austin Geological Society. She serves as an advisor for the Association for Women in Science.

Doe, J. (2016). Craters. In A History of the Moon (pp. 148-167). Chicago, IL: University of Chicago Press.
Doe, J. (2014, June 12). Should Humans Travel to Mars. The Northwest Herald, p. C7.
Doe, J. (2012). Portrait of a Young Girl on the Moon [Oil on canvas]. Prestigious Art Gallery, San Antonio, TX.

2014: Award for Willingness to Teach Online Courses, Texas State University
2012: Special Award for Services to NASA, National Aeronautics and Space Administration
1993: Presidential Physical Fitness Award, President William Clinton
